data.title: 2D Shader Editor nodes problem
data.body:
Not everything seem to work about 2D Shader Editor:
1. When using uniforms, and setting it's values from inspector of object that uses this shader, they seem to not apply on the shader at all... Values seem to stay unchanged.default.
2. When using Uniforms I get this error after pluging everything up and saving the shader:
 core/io/resource_format_binary.cpp:1417 - Can't save RIDs - with a red square on the left
( don't know what that means here ).
3. It happened to me once, that the RGB constant was giving me totaly wrong output ( B was not working at all, G was setting G and B thesame value (?!?!!), and R was ok ). I happened very single time, and I cant reproduce it now... It wasn't my fault for sure. 
4. I've also included 2 proposals about shader editor's gui to UI Rewrite Plan.

It works great anyways. Love to see the output in realtime on the preview! =]

data.title: Segfault when scanning directories containing symlinks on Linux
data.body: I set `global/autoscan_project_path` to `"/home/user/devel"` and godot crashed with a segfault. Resetting it to `""` fixed the issue and it started normally.

data.title: Exported game crashes but not in editor
data.body:
In my current project, the exported Windows executable crashes. It works completely fine in the editor, but when exported only the "boot image" appears and then a "Test.exe has stopped working".

PROJECT: https://www.dropbox.com/s/caiujrc668pcpdm/BuggyProject.7z
EXPORTED EXECUTABLE: https://www.dropbox.com/s/f6oae4i3o5ydyaw/Executable.exe

I use the stable release (1.0) hosted on godotengine.org, and I've used the export templates provided on the website the 17th of January. Everything has been done on Windows 8.1, and previous projects have been exported without trouble.

data.title: `thread_model=2` causes Godot to exit with SIGSEGV when opening project.
data.body:
This happens since 2ef5a342e34df3863ac512bb3673eba28f15e9f4.
Removing the line from `engine.cfg` makes opening the project possible again.
Setting the project setting `thread_model` back to multi-threaded (=`2`) causes the problem to return.
No error messages are displayed.

https://github.com/ScyDev/godot/tree/master/demos/crashes/recursive_reference_print_crash

data.title: Limit visibility of lights
data.body:
In scenario, when we need to hide geometry to show what's inside, in case, when we assume geometry is still there (character enters house and we remove wall of the house to show what happens inside, but the wall is physically assumed here, we just get it out of the way of our sight), but
light is get away.
Example:. Darkness outside. Character enters lit house. When he (lets tame our RigidBody) opens the door, we see some light getting through. He closes door behind, and everything is dark again. But now we want to see what happens in house, and it is not first-person game. So we do only thing we can - remove house wall to see what happens inside, and all surrounded darkness becomes lit, which is wrong, as we really did not remove wall, we just showing what happens inside house.

data.title: Suddenly no print() output in the console
data.body:
Happens when printing inside a loop. If it's an endless loop or just very many iterations, all the print() calls inside the loop will never show. 
Every print() should be flushed to the output as soon as it is issued.

All you get is:

*\* Debug Process Started **
*\* Debug Process Stopped **

data.title: win64 official releases are not 64bits. They are all 32bits. Scons does not compile 64bits with Mingw64.
data.body:
Hi,

Like i have discussed with you on IRC already, none of the official win64 releases (from RC2 to stable1.0) are actual 64bit version. They are all 32bits.

Cross compilation from linux using Mingw64 does not compile to 64bits, because scons uses `i686-w64-mingw32-g++` instead of `x86-64-w64-mingw32-g++`.
## also, for windows users who compile using Visual Studio C++ 2010 express

Visual Studio C++ 2010 express does not support 64 bits compilation by default. It will always compile to 32bits without warning whatever `scons bits=64`.
For 64bits support, you need to install extra packages (yahoo it, or duckduckgo it to find it), and when you'll run the the vcvarsall.bat, you'll have to add extra argument : `vcvarsall.bat amd64`.
## how to test if a .EXE is 32bit or 64bit application ?
### under linux or mingw msys terminal :

Using the ``file myapp.exe` command line.
If it replies `PE32 executable ... 80x86`, then it is 32bits.
If it replies `PE32+ exectabke ...x86-64`, then it is 64bits.
### under windows 7 or 8 64bits:

Run the .EXE, then Ctrl+Alt+Delete, then click "Task Manager", look for your .EXE into the Running Applications. If there is a `(32bits)`, then it is 32 bits ... if nothing, then it is 64 bits ..

Other test : right click on you .EXE, click "Properties", then "Compatibility Tab", check the "Compatibility mode" checkbox. If the combo-list contains Windows 95 or 98, it is a 32bits application. Else, it is 64bits.

data.title: Calling move(...) on KinematicBody crashes game
data.body:
[my project file](http://www.mediafire.com/download/vve1kwi430guiuv/KinematicTest.zip)  
So, I was working on a small project when I noticed this crash. I created a simple project, and indeed calling move(...) on a KinematicBody crashes the game _without any information why that just happened_. I built Godot from source and this error persists.  
This is the script that I have attached to a KinematicBody:  

```
extends KinematicBody

func _ready():
    set_fixed_process(true)

func _fixed_process(delta):
    #This line crashes the game:
    move(Vector3(0, -1, 0))
    pass

```

data.title: [Request] Reload scene button

data.body: Holding shift key to draw new anchor point only in n*45 degrees ( also perpendicularly ) according to the last one, would be a big adventage. So as snaping not only to grid but also ie. to other anchor points.

data.title: Can't select more then one anchor point
data.body:
When editing some polygon - like Polygon2D or CollisionPolygon2D and using box selection tool, the only thing that can be selected are whole objects, but can't select just a couple of anchor points to move them simultaneously.

It should be done in this way:
- drag a selection box to select anchors
- click on one of them and drag or use arrow keys to move them
  like in Adobe Illustrator or any other vector graphics editor

data.title: Keep existing, merge with new import mode doesn't work
data.body:
Keep existing, merge with new mode doesn't work. It behaves like Keep existing, ignore new,
not doing anything.

To reproduce:
1. Import simple scene, 5-7 cubes is ok. For my tests I've parented it (parent to child - 1 2 3 4 5) in Blender. Set import option first time to overwrite existing, next - merge wit new.
2. In imported scene, rename first Spatial to something interesting, then add StaticBody as parent
to first spatial, and set Cube1 as parent to it.
3. Add another StaticBody  as a child to first StaticBody and parent Cube2 to it.
4. Save the scene and go back to Blender. Add Cube6 as a child to Cube5. Export scene again.
5. On the upper right corner you will see red marker, press it and select Save & Re-import.
Observe nothing is updated. Try Import 3D scene again, but select Keep existing, merge with new for both choises now - observe nothing again.
Delete Cube5. Select Import 3D scene with the same options - observe that Cube5 is not added back.

data.title: Pr - Fixed a bug where a user could add a cyclical dependency, causing a crash.
data.body: This fix prevents a user from adding a scene instance when the current scene exists somewhere inside of that potential instance. Thus, it also prevents a scene from having an instance of itself. Either of these scenarios would cause a crash.

data.title: [Request] Shader editor for 2D Shaders
data.body: I would really like to see node shader editor for 2D shaders.

data.title: is_on_screen() not working on children of CanvasLayer
data.body:
If the parent node is CanvasLayer, the is_on_screen() will not work in child node.

More information. is_on_screen() will always return false if the parent node is CanvasLayer.

data.title: Simplex Noise functions (2D, 3D, and 4D)
data.body:
**[Simplex Noise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplex_noise)** (also known as improved Perlin Noise) has many uses in modern game development, as it lies at the heart of procedural generation. Infinite terrain, voxel worlds, clouds, and just about any texture with realistic, natural patterns can be generated using Simplex Noise. It's commonplace in modern game engines.
## Simple examples of simplex noise use:
- **3D simplex noise for 2D animation** _(passing through the third dimension over time)_: http://blog.bdero.me/some-simplex-noise.html
- **2D simplex noise for 3D terrain generation:** http://blog.bdero.me/infinite-simplex-noise-map-3d.html
## Example implementations:

Fortunately, it's also pretty easy to implement.
- **JavaScript implementation:** https://github.com/jwagner/simplex-noise.js/blob/ecfa36aed21d56b298143633b30be554754f3410/simplex-noise.js#L139-L262
- **Python implementation:** https://code.google.com/p/battlestar-tux/source/browse/procedural/simplexnoise.py#243
- **C++ implementation:** https://code.google.com/p/battlestar-tux/source/browse/procedural/simplexnoise.cpp#243

The ideal implementation would involve allowing the user to set the RNG's seed somehow (whether it's set using a separate function in advance or passed as a parameter to the noise functions), and exposing the noise functions in "@GDScript", which might look something like this:

``` python
float simplex2d(x, y)
float simplex3d(x, y, z)
```

data.title: Project Manager spits errors after deleting projects
data.body:
If a project has moved or been deleted from disk, launching the Project Manager will spit this out:

ERROR: _load_recent_projects:  Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. Continuing..:
At:  tools/editor/project_manager.cpp:523

It's a hassle to clear out old projects that don't exist anymore from the editor_settings.xml file, due to the XML saver's complete lack of sorting, but this is the only way (Editor Settings doesn't seem to allow removal there, either). This is another case where a more friendly format (OpenDDL-based) would be called for. See also #1167.

Ideally, old projects that no longer exist on disk should be removed automatically from the editor_settings.xml file, along with the recently-opened scenes stuff. I see no really compelling reason to hang onto it. And the errors might scare or confuse newbies, too.
